questions.questionText: What patterns do you see in the rock? Can you describe the different colors and stripes?

rubric.exceeds: Student identifies multiple colors (tan, brown, white) and clearly describes that the rock has stripes or layers stacked on top of each other, using words like "stripes," "bands," or "layers."
rubric.meets: Student names at least two colors in the rock and describes that there are stripes or layers visible.
rubric.approaching: Student identifies at least one color or mentions that the rock has stripes/layers, but descriptions lack detail or clarity.
rubric.beginning: Student makes a minimal attempt to describe the rock's colors or patterns with vague or mostly inaccurate observations.

questions.questionText: Why do you think the rock has these different colored stripes instead of being all one color?

rubric.exceeds: Student infers that different materials or sediments came from different sources and were layered over time, showing understanding that the stripes represent different deposits.
rubric.meets: Student suggests a reasonable explanation such as different materials or sediments being added at different times to create the layers.
rubric.approaching: Student attempts an explanation but it is vague or only partially connected to the idea of different materials or layering (e.g., "different stuff mixed together").
rubric.beginning: Student provides a minimal or unclear response with little attempt to explain why the stripes have different colors.

questions.questionText: If each stripe took a very long time to form, what would happen to our world if we could speed up time and watch this rock form really fast?

rubric.exceeds: Student explains that if time were sped up, we would see the layers form quickly and could watch the rock change, demonstrating understanding that the rock formation process normally takes a very long time.
rubric.meets: Student explains that we would see the rock form faster or layers being added more quickly, showing understanding of the connection between time and formation.
rubric.approaching: Student attempts to connect time to the formation process but the explanation is unclear or incomplete (e.g., "it would go fast").
rubric.beginning: Student provides a minimal response that does not clearly address how speeding up time would affect the rock formation process.

questions.questionText: Look at the smooth, flat layers. What do you think pressed down on these layers to make them so flat and smooth?

rubric.exceeds: Student infers that weight, pressure, or heavy materials (sediment, rocks, water, or soil) pressing down on the layers over time caused them to become flat and smooth.
rubric.meets: Student suggests that pressure or weight from above flattened and smoothed the layers, showing basic understanding of compaction.
rubric.approaching: Student attempts an explanation involving something pressing down but the reasoning is vague or incomplete (e.g., "something heavy was on top").
rubric.beginning: Student provides a minimal or unclear response with little attempt to explain what caused the layers to become flat and smooth.
